title: Using Multiple GitHub PATs for Personal and Org Repositories
context: User needed to push to both personal and organization GitHub repositories over HTTPS using separate Personal Access Tokens (PATs).
keyIdea: Store multiple GitHub tokens in ~/.git-credentials and distinguish them by adding 'username@' before github.com in each repo's remote URL, allowing Git to use the correct credentials automatically.
commands:
git config --global credential.helper store
nano ~/.git-credentials
# Add lines:
# https://mc-deltautils:github_pat_XXXX@github.com
# https://eikhren:github_pat_YYYY@github.com
git remote set-url origin https://eikhren@github.com/eikhren/xhGen.git
git remote set-url origin https://mc-deltautils@github.com/mc-deltautils/<org-repo>.git
git fetch
explanation: By storing both tokens in ~/.git-credentials and prefixing each remote URL with the matching username (e.g., eikhren@github.com), Git treats each as a distinct credential entry, allowing you to push to both personal and organization repos without conflicts or re-authentication.

reusabilityNotes.whenToReuse: Whenever you need to work with multiple GitHub accounts or organizations using HTTPS tokens on the same machine.
reusabilityNotes.pitfalls: Ensure you prefix each remote URL with the correct username@github.com, or Git will pick the wrong token. Avoid storing plaintext tokens on shared systems.
